headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Genworth Financial's First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. My name is June, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded fo
componenttext: Good morning, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Genworth Financial's First Quarter 2012 Earnings Conference Call. My name is June, and I will be your coordinator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. [Operator Instructions] I would now like to turn the presentation over to Georgette Nicholas, Senior Vice President of Investor Relations. Ms. Nicholas, you may proceed.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thank you, operator. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for Genworth's first quarter earnings call. Our press release and financial supplement were released last evening. Additional information regarding U.S. Mortgage Insurance and Investments are
componenttext:
Thank you, operator. Good morning, and thank you for joining us for Genworth's first quarter earnings call. Our press release and financial supplement were released last evening. Additional information regarding U.S. Mortgage Insurance and Investments are posted to our website concurrent with our release. Additional information on Australian Mortgage Insurance was posted to our website earlier this morning. Today, you will hear from 2 of our business leaders, starting with Marty Klein, our acting Chief Executive Officer; followed by Jerome Upton, our Global Mortgage Insurance Chief Financial Officer. Following our prepared comments, we will open the call up for a question-and-answer period. In addition to our speakers, Pat Kelleher, Executive Vice President and Chief Executive Officer of our Insurance and Wealth Management division; Kevin Schneider, President and CEO of our Global Mortgage Insurance segment; Daniel Sheehan, Chief Investment Officer; and Buck Stinson, President, Insurance Products for our U.S. Life Insurance segment will be available today questions. 
As regards to the forward-looking statements and the use of non-GAAP financial information, some of the statements we make during the call this morning may contain forward-looking statements. Our actual results may differ materially from such statements. We advise you to read the cautionary note regarding forward-looking statements in our earnings release and the risk factors section of our most recent Annual Report on Form 10-K, filed with the SEC in February 2012.
This morning's discussion also includes non-GAAP financial measures that we believe may be meaningful to investors. In our supplement and earnings release, non-GAAP measures have been reconciled to GAAP where required in accordance with SEC rules.
And finally, when we talk about International Protection and International Mortgage Insurance segment results, please note that all percentage changes exclude the impact of foreign exchange. And now, let me turn the call over to Marty Klein.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Georgette, and good morning. Today I will provide an overview of the business and capital results in the first quarter. But first, I want to acknowledge and thank Mike Fraizer for his contributions to the company over the years. From his early day
componenttext:
Thanks, Georgette, and good morning. Today I will provide an overview of the business and capital results in the first quarter. But first, I want to acknowledge and thank Mike Fraizer for his contributions to the company over the years. From his early days at GE, through the IPO in 2004 and recent financial crisis. Under Mike's tenure as CEO, he has nurtured the commitment for making a difference for the people who rely on us most, customers, policyholders, employees, communities and industry. This has helped set a strong foundation to build from. Genworth has established a strong competitive position in our leadership lines, loyal customers and distributors, the very talented and dedicated group of employees across the company. With this transition, we will be very focused on executing the actions needed to rebuild value for shareholders as well as bondholders. We will continue to meet the needs of our customers while we improve the performance of our businesses, maintain strong liquidity and generate and manage capital. I look forward to working with the board and with our team to manage this transition. 
Now turning to results. First quarter saw good progress in U.S. Mortgage Insurance, stable performance in Canada as well as our investment portfolio, very disappointing results on Australia, which resulted in delay in the timing of our planned minority IPO. Unfortunately, it overshadowed the progress we made in other areas. 
I'll begin with the Global Mortgage Insurance division where the reported loss in the quarter was $36 million compared with net operating income of $16 million from the prior year. Let me give some perspectives on each of the mortgage platforms. In Australia, the operating loss was $21 million. Results reflected a $53 million after-tax impact from our service strengthening in Australia. This is driven by the combination of accelerated processing of delinquencies in our pipeline from 2011 through foreclosure declaim, along with higher current and anticipated the severity that we identified as we went deeper in individual claim cases during March and updated estimates for property price declines in certain submarkets, particularly in Queensland. The delinquencies we are dealing with are concentrated from geographic, and borrower profile standpoint. They are in Queensland in the 2007 and 2008 vintages and with small business owners and self-employed borrowers. Jerome will be talking in much more detail about the Transcend businesses results in Australia in just a few minutes. 
Before I move on, I'd like to discuss the frustration regarding Australia MI development. I appreciate your frustration and as part of our leadership transition, we will actively review and seek to improve our processes to avoid such frustration in the future. 
Turning now to Canada. Operating earnings were $37 million for the quarter, down from $51 million in the prior year. Unemployment is trending lower and home prices are stable sequentially. In the quarter, the business experienced lower earned premiums as the larger 2007 and 2008 books of business continue to season. The loss ratio decreased to 2.6 sequentially to 38%, as overall delinquencies were down 5% from the prior quarter. I'd like to note that we maintain strong capital positions in both Australia and Canada. The operating loss in other countries in the International Mortgage segment was $9 million from losses driven by the European economic environment, primarily in Ireland. 
Moving to U.S. MI. Results improved in the quarter to a net operating loss of $43 million from a net operating loss of $96 million in the prior quarter and $83 million in the prior year. Flow NIW increased 50% over the prior year, this overall private mortgage insurance penetration improved but it was down 6% sequentially reflecting competitor pricing pressure on our market share in certain channels. Estimated market share remains flat in about 14% as we maintain our pricing and underwriting position. We continue to monitor the impact of competitor pricing on our market share. Our total floor delinquencies went down 11% from the prior year, with new delinquencies down both year-over-year and sequentially reflecting the continued burn through of the 2005 through 2008 books. We default on modifications continued as expected. Loss mitigation savings in the quarter increased to $158 million as claims mitigation benefits offset a 5% decline in workouts as HAMP modification wind down. Our risk-to-capital in GEMICO was relatively stable, up about 0.5 points to 33.4:1 in the quarter. Genworth Residential Mortgage Insurance Corporation or GRMAC is a subsidiary of GEMICO had capital increased modestly to approximately $78 million with the risk-to-capital ratio of 2.4:1 giving it about 1 year of new business capacity across 50 states, pending our part level and regarding GSE approval. 
Shifting for a minute from quarterly results, I want to discuss some anxiety organization moves in our global MI division. As you know, we efficiently re-segmented our businesses around the need to be served into 3 divisions, Global Mortgage Insurance, Assurance in Wealth Management led by Pat Kelleher and Corporate Runoff. Now we're taking the next natural step in our MI businesses to reflect this alignment. So as you saw in separate press release, I'm very pleased to announce that Kevin Schneider will become President and CEO of the Global Mortgage Insurance division, bringing his experience and depth to the entire division. Gupta who is head of variety of roles in USMI and most recently served as Chief Commercial Officer of our product, pricing and marketing and sales take over as President of USMI. 
Let's turn back to results and discuss the Insurance and Wealth Management division with reported operating earnings of $81 million down from $127 million in the prior year. These results reflect the first life-block sale transaction which generated $170 million of statutory capital benefit and which generated an associated after tax GAAP net loss of $41 million. Excluding life block sales transaction, earnings in the quarter were $122 million. Life Insurance earnings were $47 million for the quarter, excluding the life block sale transaction loss, which is up from $42 million in the prior year. Firm UL and other universal life sales were flat compared to the fourth quarter. We expect sales to moderate going forward as we make further targeted changes to manage the sales mix and volume, in order to manage capital. Finally, we continue to use reinsurance and new business to manage capital effectively. 
Long-term care earnings were $35 million for the quarter. Overall results were consistent with the prior year with lower mortality being offset by higher premiums and a stable investment yields through hedging program. We had 2 reserve items in the quarter. The first item is a $10 million of favorable adjustment related to a systems conversion which is taking place in several stages. Second item is the $7 million increase in reserves associated with an improved methodology for incurred but not reported claims that will provide a better estimate of cost and reduced quarterly fluctuations going forward. Additionally, our previously announced premium rate increase on the majority of the older policies begun to take effect. We still expect the continued impact in 2012 will add about $50 million in additional premium of which $10 million was reflected in the first quarter, and about $60 million in 2013 when fully implemented. We continue to closely watch the performance of the older business, and we'll assess the need for additional rate increases accordingly. 
The block of newer issued policies have the loss ratio of 52%. Finally, we reinsured about 40% of the new long-term-care product to manage capital and risk. Fixed annuity's earnings were $33 million as we had a favorable adjustment for the state guarantee fund assessment. These annuity sales were down slightly from the fourth quarter as we continue to manage new business to meet or exceed target returns in the low interest rate environment. International Protection earnings were $5 million, down from both the prior year and prior quarter. The underwriting margin decreased 7 points from both the prior year and prior quarter to 14%. New claim registrations in Europe decreased 7% versus the prior year, and increased of 13% versus the prior quarter primarily driven by Southern Europe, and a combined of less favorable claim reserve adjustment drove the loss ratio up 7 points in the quarter to 23%. Total revenue, excluding foreign exchange was flat versus the prior quarter and down 17% versus the prior year. There were several items in the quarter that we do not expect to impact this business going forward. Higher premium taxes related to a tax court ruling and lower tax benefits impacted the quarter by approximately $7 million in total. Additionally, although operating expenses were down versus the prior quarter, there was a $3 million impact related to resident expenses in additional profit share expenses. In light of the continued slow consumer lending environment in Europe, expense actions have been taken to mitigate these impacts. Wealth management earnings were $12 million for the quarter. Turning to capital, U.S. Life company risk-based capital ratio topped 425%, 20 points from year and as we completed the first life block sales transaction. The capital benefit of this transaction was larger than initially estimated due to refined estimates of these associated tax benefits. The unsigned statutory surplus at the end of the first quarter for the U.S. Life companies is estimated to be $215 million, while the consolidated statutory earnings for the first quarter is estimated to be $280 million, in line with statutory goals we laid out on our 2012 business goals call in February, the quarterly volatility. These goals are a high priority as we work to reestablish the regular ordinary dividend capacity for that revenues in 2013, this is  important to our shareholders and our bondholders. 
Finally, in the corporate runoff division result improved over the prior year from a variable annuity results driven by better market performance and favorable taxes. Shifting to investments, the global portfolio is performing well. For yields were 4.6% in the quarter, which is flat to the prior year and prior quarter as we redeployed cash and saw improvements in the performance of limited partnerships. We're happy that Dan Sheehan, with 18 years of broad and deep investment experience, has taken the role as our Chief Investment Officer, given Ron Jones' departure for another position. Over the last several years, Ron worked closely with Dan in our investment in for restructuring and dearest the portfolio. Ron has been a great colleague and friend and we thank him for his contributions to Genworth. 
Turning next to the holding company. We maintained ample liquidity. At the end of the first quarter, the holding company held cash and liquid securities of approximately $1.4 billion, an increase of about $465 million over the prior quarter. This increase reflects approximately $230 million of temporary tax benefits related to the tax agreements with our operating companies, that we expect to be paid to the operating companies later this year. We executed a $350 million debt offering in March of this year, and continue to navigate towards a long-term leverage ratio between 24% and 26%. After the upcoming June debt maturity, our leverage ratio will be approximately 26%. I would like to offer some perspective on how we're thinking about the current cash position of the holding company. When adjusting for the temporary taxes that will be paid later this year, and the upcoming $222 million June debt maturity, holding company has about $950 million of cash and liquid securities. That balances currently designated for target of 2x debt service coverage which is about $600 million, and an additional buffer for stress scenarios that might impact the dividend source of the holding company over the next 18 months of approximately $350 million. After the quarter ended, we received approval from Delaware Regulators for an extraordinary cash dividend from the U.S. Life companies of $100 million which is paid to the holding company in April and is not part of the quarter end numbers. We also intend to receive approximately $70 million in cash from the sale of GFIS that was completed in early April. In close consultation with the board, we continue to actively evaluate these approach is to rebuild shareholder value including for example, share repurchases. With respect to repurchase, we have studies our cash resources and the flows of the holding company balance them against our debt service needs and liquidity targets, taking into account the delay in the Australian IPO. The results of this analysis that it is unlikely that we would commence the share repurchase program in 2012. 
To conclude, while we have made headwind in many of our objectives and seen improved results in some businesses, we have much work ahead. We must continue to manage debt story performance in the life companies, navigate the challenges in European economies and their impact on our results, and actively manage and monitor experience on Australia. I look forward to working with the board and with our team of very talented employees to improve performance, generate, manage capital and liquidity and rebuild the value of Genworth. 
Let me now turn it over to Jerome to discuss Australia's results and trends.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Marty. This morning, I will provide insights on our Australia Mortgage Insurance business the first quarter trends we observed where both the number of claims and the average claim payment increased significantly particularly in March, as Genworth
componenttext:
Thanks, Marty. This morning, I will provide insights on our Australia Mortgage Insurance business the first quarter trends we observed where both the number of claims and the average claim payment increased significantly particularly in March, as Genworth and key lenders increased focus on the fault management. I will also be discussing the results of the portfolio review that was conducted given the first quarter trends that led to the reserve strengthening. I will conclude with some perspectives on business performance going forward. I will be referring to the Australia MI portfolio update presentation that has been posted to our investor website. 
Before I begin, please note the cautionary note with regard to the forward-looking statements and the basis for presenting financial information detailed on Slide 1. As shown on Slide 2, at the end of the first quarter, we had a little over $100 billion of effective risk with an overall portfolio delinquency rate of 0.54%. Our risk and force is dispersed across 4 major regions in line with the country's population and across several years of origination for vintages. Overall, our performance has been solid. However, we are seeing pressure in the Queensland region, and in the 2007 and 2008 vintages. When you drill down 1 level, our business performance is particularly impacted by the coastland Queensland area and small business and self-employed borrowers in the 2007, 2008 vintages, with each representing approximately 6% of total risk and force. I will provide more detail on these subsegments shortly. 
During late 2008 and through the first half of 2009, we strengthened guidelines and eliminated certain products which have improved performance of our most recent vintages. 
Turning to Slide 3. During the first quarter, we experienced higher losses primarily due to loss reserve strengthening of $82 million before taxes or $53 million on after-tax which was reviewed by independent third parties. The major drivers of this strengthening were: First, coastal Queensland economic downturn; two, small business, self-employed borrowers in the '07 and '08 vintages; third, the impact of lender servicing and programs; and fourth, the number of paid claims and severity. 
As you can see on Slide 4, the first key driver of the reserve strengthening was the impact of the coastal Queensland economic downturn on housing. We have identified these areas as the Far North, Sunshine Coast and Gold Coast which are principally tourist areas. You will observe the differentiated performance in these areas with peak to trough homes declines in double digits and even deeper declines on some of the 4 closed properties, as well as delinquency rates above the rest of Queensland in the overall portfolio. These areas have been hit hard by depressed tourism, particularly as the Australia dollar strengthened, lower levels of consumer and retail spending and reduced housing demand driving home prices lower. This is indicated on the left of this slide, as Queensland tourism has been particularly impacted through early 2011, but is showing early stages of recovery. This early stage recovery will not impact our delinquencies over the short term but should aid performance overtime as economic improvement work its way into the housing market. 
Turning to Slide 5, the deeper home price declines and higher average loan balances in coastal Queensland, when compared to the overall portfolio, our average paid claim on these properties is significantly higher than the overall portfolio. And a number of claims we paid as well as the average claim increased significantly on our first quarter of 2012, as we work with lenders to accelerate claim processing. 
As shown on Slide 6, second driver of the reserve strengthening was a small business of some light are in the 2007 and 2008 vintages. The segment is more relied on to resume, retail and consumer spending including rental income where these borrowers have investment properties. The lower levels of tourism and retail spending have reduced income levels on the segment and combined with higher cost of living in mortgage payments to the higher interest rates and created increased claims. On the left side of this page, we have provided details on our small business and self-employed borrower risk and force and you can see the levels included in the 2007 and 2008 vintages including Queensland, the Coastal Queensland concentrations as well as the higher delinquency rates. The impact of underwriting guidelines changes in 2008 and the first half of 2009 has significantly reduced risk and force for the segment that improve performance of more recent vintages. As you can see on the right, our average claim paid in the segment seems to be higher than the other portfolio and we have observed on increasing the number of claims paid in the average claim paid from fourth quarter to first quarter. 
Now turning to Slide 7. As we look forward to future claims development, we see delinquencies rates for the pressured subsegment such as the 2007 and '08 vintages, and the associated small business and self-employed borrower are stabilizing, allowing for the normal first quarter is seasonal increase. Newer vintages, especially 2010 and 2011 are seasoning very well at this point. In addition, we've seen improving profile going forward in the delinquency mix. On the right, we have provided some key metrics that have been produced with extensive analysis conducted on delinquency inventory. You will observe that Coastal Queensland accounts for 15% of the delinquent risk and force and later stage delinquencies categories while reducing the 10% and earlier stage delinquencies. Also, the 2007 and 2008 small business and self-employed borrowers will see  a corresponding improvement from 25% to 18%. Based on the work completed, we expect severities to decline as we work our way through the later stage delinquencies to the earlier stages. Of course, future claims development will be influenced by economic and housing market conditions as well as lender servicing. 
Moving to Slide 8. Another contributing factor was during late 2011 and into early 2012. We absorbed an extension of time from initial delinquency to claim payment with the 2 key drivers impacting the cycle: Lender servicing practices and forbearance programs. The normal cycle from delinquency is approximately 13 to 15 months, just now been expanded given current circumstances to 18 to 20 months. These delays increased our claims cost. During 2011, as delinquencies increased during the year, certain lender servicing routines fell behind which created processing delays and cost backlogs to delinquencies. In partnership with key lenders, we increased focus on default management and have seen a portion of these delinquencies come true in our first quarter results. In addition, the forbearance process sanctioned by the government has driven delays. This process allows borrowers the opportunity to submit a hardship dispute to an independent third-party to assist in its ultimate resolution. Collections and foreclosure proceedings must seize until a final determination on the hardship is reached. This can further extend the time decline payment and we are working with the government identify areas to improve the process and reduce the cycle time. 
In addition, we are actively working on servicing issues with key lenders by placing on-site resources to help accelerate decisions, advice on foreclosure strategies and improve delinquency the claim cycle time. 
As shown on Slide 9. In the first quarter of 2012, with a number of claims and the average claim payment increase significantly as Genworth and key lenders increased focus on default management. As you can see, this was more concentrated in March with a significant increase in the average claim payed as many of these claims also had higher loan balances. The observed increase in average claims size in March led us to conduct a comprehensive review of our delinquency inventory. 
Now turning to Slide 10. As a result of loss experience we saw emerge in the first quarter, we felt it necessary and prudent to strengthen loss reserves. Loss reserves are meant in an ultimate paid claims for reported delinquencies including a provision for incurred but not reported losses. In the quarter, we supplemented our normal quarterly actuarial review process with an extensive, loan-by-loan analysis of our delinquency inventory. This analysis included obtaining more up-to-date property valuations for all delinquencies, with adjustments to further stretch the home price and foreclosure. This analysis from the bases of the reserve strengthening of $82 million. It's important to note that our loss estimates assume no improvement in economic conditions and reserve adequacy maybe influenced by perspective changes in economic and housing market conditions. As you can see from the chart, the reserve adjustments were predominantly applied to the late stage delinquencies and loans currently in foreclosure, where we expect higher conversion rate to claim and higher claim severities. The limited strengthening its early stage delinquencies is supported by the changing delinquency mix profile and anticipated improving severity levels. You can think of the reserve strengthening in 2 categories: Claims and late stage delinquencies. Approximately $20 million of the reserve strengthening is related to claims to be paid during the second quarter with the residual applied to later stage delinquencies, majority of which will be paid over the remainder of the year. 
Now turning to Slide 11. Going forward, we will continue to thoroughly analyze our delinquency  inventory and update property valuations to assess or loss reserves. In addition, as mentioned earlier, we have on-site default management personnel at key lenders to help improve collections and optimize a loss mitigation decisions with an emphasis on loan workout activity, home sale prior foreclosure or an acceleration to claim. Finally, we will continue to adjust claims payment for cost outside of our policy, carefully monitor performance for small business and the self-employed borrowers as well as Coastal Queensland. 
Moving to Slide 12. As part of a deeper assessment of our portfolio, we look into other areas that could be sensitive to shifts in tourisms similar to Coastal Queensland. The results of this analysis are outlined in the table to the left, highlighting other specific tourist areas we have a much lower concentrations and lower delinquency rates. Looking broadly at the vintage analysis on the right side of the slide, you see down under performance of the 2007 and 2008 vintages would improving trends in more recent vintages. Overall, delinquency trends appear to be stabilizing. 
Now turning to Slide 13. The results for the quarter were disappointing with the reported operating loss of $21 million and a loss ratio of 154%. Stepping back from the quarterly results, our Australia Mortgage Insurance business has a history of producing strong annual results and our long-term views of this business and the market fundamentals have not changed. The revenue generation in the business is solid with over $1 billion under premium reserves and a strong investment portfolio producing investment income. In addition, we are in the process of implementing an approximate 7% price increase in the market. While we do expect to see elevated claim levels over the near term, we have used the current quarter loss emergence and other information to strengthen loss reserves we believe sufficient to cover these elevated claims. However, reserve adequacy will be dependent on future economic and housing market conditions, and the results for the next 2 quarters will be key task for these reserves. We do expect to produce an annual profit for 2012, but our quarterly results will be volatile with more  noted improvements in the second half of the year. 
Moving to Slide 14. As you can see, our capital level remains strong. Our estimated regulatory capital ratio at the first quarter is 153%. The 153% level is consistent with the ratios we reported throughout 2011. Over the past 18 to 24 months, in addition to building our capital, we have significantly diversify the capital profile in Australia, by raising $140 million of local Tier 2 debt and have significantly expanded our external reinsurance program, both in coverage levels and a number of participating reinsurers. At the in-force portfolio continues to season and is profits are generated going forward, we expect the Australian business to continue its strong generation of capital. 
Related to our planned dividend for the year, we'll expect the business to generate capital level sufficient to make the payment. However, this payment will be contingent on results for the year, approval by the Australia board and discussions with our regulator. The Australia dividend is less than 50% of the total international MI dividend for the year. 
Turning to Slide 15. We know there have been views expressed about a housing in Australia by certain parties. While others support the ongoing strength of the housing market, in this slide we highlighted the use of both bears and bulls as well as our own. Our views are: First, lending standards in Australia have remained strong with household formation driving housing demand. On a national level, there's a shortage of housing. The outlook for the economy remains solid, although we do expect continued areas of subregional pressure such as the coastal areas of Queensland. While home prices are high by historical measures, they have been supported by increased consumer purchasing power with home prices moderating since the second quarter of 2010. And while household indebtedness has increased, exposing consumers to rate shocks, the ratio of that disposable income has been relatively steady for several years in 150%. The majority of this that this mortgage related which can be repaid over a long period of time.  
In summary, we expect national home prices to be flat for 2012 allowing further digestion of historical home price increases. In closing, we are disappointed with the quarterly performance but our approach has been to make adjustments to put this issue behind us. Importantly, we must leverage the experience to improve our processes going forward. And in all of this, our long-term view of the Australia Mortgage Insurance business has not changed, the business and market fundamentals remain in place and are strong. Now, let me open the call up for Q&A.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question here in queue is Andrew Kligerman with UBS.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: A few questions. First, on Australia, you say that you expect to be profitable again and in particular in the second half of 2012. Does that mean that you get back to sort of high-40s loss ratios that you were seeing there? And how confident are you? Seco
componenttext: A few questions. First, on Australia, you say that you expect to be profitable again and in particular in the second half of 2012. Does that mean that you get back to sort of high-40s loss ratios that you were seeing there? And how confident are you? Second, risk-to-capital is 28.6:1 across all the U.S. MI. How confident are you that you won't need to infuse new capital into the MI entities? Thirdly, International Protection, 23% loss ratio the last 4 quarters ranged from 15% to 17%. What's the likelihood that we can get back to 15% to 17% and when.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Jerome Upton. With respect to your Australia question, I run profitability in the second half. I would just say, I break this down into 3 buckets, and that is our current delinquency inventory and the mix that we've seen come true, the loss emerge
componenttext: This is Jerome Upton. With respect to your Australia question, I run profitability in the second half. I would just say, I break this down into 3 buckets, and that is our current delinquency inventory and the mix that we've seen come true, the loss emergence in March that we saw, and the approach that we took to record our reserve strengthening of $82 million to put the issue behind us with respect to what we see in delinquency portfolio. So we've used our best information to book that $82 million, again to put it behind us but facts and circumstances could come true in the second and third quarter. That could call into question, that reserve adequacy, and we want to see 2 to 3 quarters come through to prove that out. Number two, the pressured segments that we're seeing, the '07 and the '08, both in Coastal Queensland and the Queensland in general, we see  stabilizing trend there, but again we want to see the proved points come through the second and third quarter. And again, in my prepared remarks, we took underwriting actions particularly related to some of the pressure points we saw in '07 and '08. And you've seen the recent vintages and the new vintage performance has improved as a result of that. So we'll be profitable for the year based on our best estimate. Right now, we're going to be very volatile in the quarter by quarter basis. I can't make the call but really, you want to see the next 2 to 3 quarters and proof come through on our reserve adjustment of $82 million, and the vintage, the '07 and '08 in Coastal Queensland come through we're seeing stability. We want to see that come through.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's Marty. Let me start up on your question on USMI and then I will turn it over to Kevin. I'd start out by observing that the performance we saw in the first quarter was certainly in line with our plan on what we talked about on our February call. And s
componenttext: It's Marty. Let me start up on your question on USMI and then I will turn it over to Kevin. I'd start out by observing that the performance we saw in the first quarter was certainly in line with our plan on what we talked about on our February call. And since we don't have any current plans to contribute capital to USMI on based on what we're seeing, I'm also kind of stepping back up server that we certainly encourage days sales outstanding private equity money begin to flow into the space obviously have pretty high standards of returns and I think that confirms our view around the value of new business that is being written, we encourage to see that quite frankly. When you think about capitals we talked in the past and Kevin talked about some links, it's really not a bright line in the sand risk to capital is obviously 1 metric, it's easy for investors to look at regulators look much deeper than that claims is the solvency reserve levels and we think right now, with the waivers we've got in GEMICO in 44 states along with the GRMAC which is got capital right across 50 states, we think we're pretty good shape. Kevin, why don’t you speak to performance we saw in the quarter?

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Just to piggyback on that a bit, Andrew. In the first quarter, in the metrics that we laid out for investors in our February call where operating in line with our metrics. In fact, a little bit favorable when you get down and look at internally in terms o
componenttext: Just to piggyback on that a bit, Andrew. In the first quarter, in the metrics that we laid out for investors in our February call where operating in line with our metrics. In fact, a little bit favorable when you get down and look at internally in terms of what our expectations were from our overall surplus standpoint. Our penetration in the market is going up, our NIW is basically in line with our expectations. Our reserves and our delinquency development, the experience we're seeing there are totally in line with user provisioning we did in the past. Our loss mitigation trends, our online or in fact, a little bit ahead of our overall expectations going forward. And we think that's been sort of a nice outcome for us, the new delinquencies which we said we are expecting would be down about 20% year-over-year first quarter they're down a little more than that, the 23-ish level. So the charts that we put up on USMI illustrate all of those trends that I just showed. And again, we are very comfortable at this point in time that we don't have any real working closely with our regulators and the GSEs on that. And if things change we'll let you know but the current and we don't see any word.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: And then Pat why don’t you take the LPI question?
componenttext: And then Pat why don’t you take the LPI question?

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: Sure. I guess the way that I look at this is that we reported income of $5 million for the quarter, Marty had indicated that there were several items, taxes, restructuring cost and one other item that are not expected to impact that business going forward
componenttext: Sure. I guess the way that I look at this is that we reported income of $5 million for the quarter, Marty had indicated that there were several items, taxes, restructuring cost and one other item that are not expected to impact that business going forward. So when you adjust for that, the earnings if you look at it is about $15 million for the quarter, which is clearly down from the $19 million in the fourth quarter and about $25 million in the first quarter of last year. And that is primarily due to the loss ratio. And what I'd say is that there are several markets are several countries that are, I say, performing worse than the recent trends from an unemployment perspective and from an economy growth perspective. And that's what impacted our results. I'd look at it as a smaller version of what we saw in 2009 with the general downturn in Europe. And there, what we needed to do was a step back, look at our contracts and look at our ability to reprice and take measures to improve the profitability of the business going forward. While this is a lesser impact clearly than what we saw a couple of years ago we would take the same approach and expect improved underwriting results over a 3 to 4 quarter timeframe.

componenttextpreview: Geoff, this is Jerome. Thanks for the question. In the second half of 2011, we did see increase on the liquidity levels and reviewed and observed the lender processing delays and we begun to work more closely with those lenders to improve the collection a
componenttext: Geoff, this is Jerome. Thanks for the question. In the second half of 2011, we did see increase on the liquidity levels and reviewed and observed the lender processing delays and we begun to work more closely with those lenders to improve the collection and default management techniques. It did accelerate some of the older delinquencies coming through. And as those came through in the first quarter, the claim pay count did decrease in January and February. But it was the margin loss emergence and average claims size that really gave rise to our deep dive on the delinquency inventory and the extensive review that we undertook to strengthen loss reserves of $82 million. We'll always take a look at process, we'll always endeavor to improve, but it really was those claim payments in March that gave rise to the strengthening.

componenttext: I apologize that the conclusion of your question were a little bit but it is coming in. On the curtailment side, we have begun to have a little bit of benefit from that curtailment experience as we've worked through all the opportunities to make sure all those -- all the questions about those claims around that curtailment and the feedback from the servicers and we had a bit of offsetting benefit of that in the quarter. I would say it's about $15 million in the quarter.

componenttext: It's Pat. I'll take it. Yes, we completed the first life block transaction in the quarter. It was really our answer to freeing up capital from business with good mortality and persistency, but we basically had the lower return due to higher locked in reserve financing cost. When you look at the after tax capital benefit, a portion of it related to the statutory earnings and a portion of it really related to bringing capital that was in capital securitization structures back on to the statutory balance sheet. So the capital benefit of $170 million was much larger than the statutory income benefit, which was in the neighborhood of $65 million to $70 million. Does that help?

componenttext: Question again on the Australian MI unit. I guess there were a couple of other people who tried it differently so I'm going to try it in a different way as well. Looking at the supplement Page 43 and looking at the delinquency rates and if you look at September 11, 2011, delinquencies rates was 59 versus December was 55. So if you look at the delinquency rate, there was no indication of that there is trouble in the unit. And obviously, you guys indicate that the frequency the foreclosure happen that severity was higher than expected. My question is, the delinquency rates that are being reported as well, how -- is there any time lag and how much of a handle do you have when things start going south on all these loans.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: This is Jerome. You're breaking up quite a bit there. I think I got your question. If I missed it, please come back at me and we'll try again. Our delinquency rates have improved quarter-over-quarter. And the loss emergence that we saw in March was less a
componenttext: This is Jerome. You're breaking up quite a bit there. I think I got your question. If I missed it, please come back at me and we'll try again. Our delinquency rates have improved quarter-over-quarter. And the loss emergence that we saw in March was less about the delinquencies, the delinquencies count, the number of delinquencies and more about the mix that was in those delinquencies. Again, there were some processing delays. The issue delinquencies we begun to process in the first quarter, we saw the loss emergence in March, and those delinquencies as we've shown in the analysis, many of the late stage delinquencies have a higher mix in the areas that have given some economic pressure. So I think that was the answer to your first question. If you could come back to me with your second question, that would be helpful because you were breaking up.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: The second question, and I have follow-up as well. The second question, is there a time lag in capturing this delinquency rates? Do the lenders inform the -- and do you have a handle when things start becoming delinquent to capture them quickly? And a fol
componenttext: The second question, and I have follow-up as well. The second question, is there a time lag in capturing this delinquency rates? Do the lenders inform the -- and do you have a handle when things start becoming delinquent to capture them quickly? And a follow-up is the addition I understand you've added on an after-tax  this $53 million, but when I look at the average claims, obviously that went up because of the severity increase and when I look at the delinquent loans, I see coverage is only around 55%. So I'm just trying to see if that is adequate.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: So Annan, the answer to your first question, is there is a little bit of a delay in the delinquency inventory reporting to us by a couple of months. And one of the things that we have done around that is we are actively working with our lenders. We have o
componenttext: So Annan, the answer to your first question, is there is a little bit of a delay in the delinquency inventory reporting to us by a couple of months. And one of the things that we have done around that is we are actively working with our lenders. We have on-site personnel there to give us better perspective and insight on those delinquencies as they come through. So we do feel like we have a hand almost delinquencies, but yes, there is a little bit of a lag. Does that help?

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: I just have some comments. As a shareholder, I'm very disappointed that the lead director is not on the call. And if someone there could comment on the future direction, the leadership direction of the company. And also, does anyone have any thoughts on t
componenttext: I just have some comments. As a shareholder, I'm very disappointed that the lead director is not on the call. And if someone there could comment on the future direction, the leadership direction of the company. And also, does anyone have any thoughts on the company being put up for sale into other avenues for -- to enhance shareholder value. And third thing I have was, I thought I heard at the top of the conversation that we have new processes in place. And then I heard that we're under review the processes. So if there could be some clarification there. And also, could you give us some concrete steps, one, two, three, what you're doing right now to enhance shareholder value.

headline: Genworth Financial Inc., Q1 2012 Earnings Call, May 02, 2012
componenttextpreview: It's Marty. I'll take those questions. I would say that Jim Riepe, who's our lead director and is also named nonexecutive chair, is very, very actively involved for quite some time and continue to be very involved and Jim and I speak multiple times as he
componenttext: It's Marty. I'll take those questions. I would say that Jim Riepe, who's our lead director and is also named nonexecutive chair, is very, very actively involved for quite some time and continue to be very involved and Jim and I speak multiple times as he does with other members of management. So he is very involved but he's leaving it to the management team to handle earnings call, which is typically the case. With respect to the sale of the company or other strategic aspects, I'd say that the most important thing we can be doing right now is improve the performance of our businesses, which is very important to give us the flexibility to execute various strategy. So working on the statutory performance of the light business to return to the ordinary dividend capacity, regular ordinary dividend capacity is very, very important. Working very actively on the turn in USMI to hopefully profitable next year and managing Australia losses, those are all very important things because as we manage those performances, we'll get a much better position to take better actions to improve shareholder value. The board in the meantime is very engaged on strategies, which could be ultimately a number of different things but ultimately we have to put ourselves in the place by building the financial strength of the company by improving performance. Thank you for your question. Oh, I'm sorry, I actually neglected it, to talk about your process change. We're very confident on our quarterly closing process, let me just start out with that. We are undertaking a review which will start beginning next week to make sure that our processes identify business trends as soon as absolutely possible. And if we're able to identify any of those improvements, we're simply going to make them, and we'll do that in our other businesses as well. We're certainly not aware of any process breakdowns, but we'll take a look at those and make the improvements accordingly. Thanks.
